importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky earned international acclaim as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in November 2007, establishing himself as one of the country’s most promising young talents.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
The New York Times hired Naroditsky as a chess columnist in 2022, marking a significant milestone in his public educational outreach.
The 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence for Naroditsky, reflecting his lasting impact on the chess community.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2007 to 2025 captures Naroditsky’s rise from youth champion to international educator and online influencer, highlighting the evolution of digital engagement in chess.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He earned the title of grandmaster before high school graduation and won multiple national youth championships.
He became a widely followed chess educator through livestreams on YouTube and Twitch, with nearly half a million subscribers on YouTube and 340,000 followers on Twitch.
Naroditsky was a regular contributor to Chess Life magazine and became a chess columnist for The New York Times in 2022.
He served as a head coach at the Charlotte Chess Center in Charlotte, North Carolina.
His death was announced by the Charlotte Chess Center, with no cause of death or location provided.
The International Chess Federation and Saint Louis Chess Club publicly mourned his passing, recognizing him as a 'beloved pillar of the chess community'.
The 2025 US Chess Championship included a moment of silence in his honor.
Naroditsky’s family has requested privacy following his death.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a 29-year-old American chess grandmaster born in the San Francisco Bay Area, died unexpectedly. He rose to prominence as a young prodigy, winning international youth championships and earning the grandmaster title before high school. A passionate educator, he became widely known through livestreamed games on YouTube and Twitch, reaching nearly half a million subscribers and 340,000 followers. He contributed to major chess publications like Chess Life and The New York Times, and served as head coach at the Charlotte Chess Center. The international chess community, including the International Chess Federation and Saint Louis Chess Club, publicly mourned his death, with a moment of silence observed during the 2025 US Chess Championship. His legacy includes making chess accessible and engaging for millions through digital platforms and his enduring influence on both players and educators worldwide.

title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
